rules.title: Office Application Spawning Suspicious PowerShell with Gaza Cybergang Patterns
rules.description: Detects Office apps spawning PowerShell with encoded commands or suspicious expressions associated with Palestinian-themed decoy documents used by Gaza Cybergang
falsepositives: Legitimate document macros using PowerShell automation (rare)
Administrator troubleshooting Office-PowerShell integrations

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel via Curl and Malicious PowerShell
rules.description: Detects exfiltration over C2 channel using curl library initiated by suspicious PowerShell activity, particularly associated with Gaza Cybergang TTPs such as encoded commands and script execution from Office applications.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use curl through PowerShell for automation
PowerShell scripts initiated from Office documents in authorized macro-enabled workflows
Developers testing API calls using curl within PowerShell from document templates
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Execution with Gaza Cybergang Patterns and Office Parent Process
rules.description: Detects PowerShell execution that includes Gaza Cybergang specific patterns such as -EncodedCommand or Invoke-Expression, especially when spawned by Office applications, indicating possible malicious activity.

detection.condition: (selection_powershell and (selection_encoded or selection_invoke)) or (selection_powershell and selection_parent_office)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell with -EncodedCommand
Scheduled tasks or automation tools that invoke PowerShell
Office add‑ins or macros that legitimately launch PowerShell for functionality

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

attacks.description: Basic phishing attack by creating a decoy document
attacks.expected_behavior: A new text file named lure.txt is created in the temporary directory and opened with the default text editor.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "'Palestinian matter lure' | Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\lure.txt -Encoding UTF8; Invoke-Item $env:TEMP\lure.txt"
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing attack using PowerShell to create and open a decoy document
attacks.expected_behavior: A new text file named lure.txt is created in the temporary directory with the specified content and then opened with the default associated program.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir $env:TEMP\phishing -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; 'Decoy document about Palestinian matters' | Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\phishing\lure.txt; Invoke-Item $env:TEMP\phishing\lure.txt"
attacks.description: Advanced phishing attack creating a directory and a decoy document with specific content
attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory named phishing is created in the temporary directory, and inside it, a text file named lure.txt is created with the specified content and then opened with the default associated program.

attacks.command: echo 'هذا المستند يحتوي على معلومات مهمة حول القضية الفلسطينية.' > /tmp/القضية_الفلسطينية.txt && cat /tmp/القضية_الفلسطينية.txt
attacks.description: Creates a decoy Arabic text file referencing Palestinian matters and displays its content.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'القضية_الفلسطينية.txt' is created in /tmp containing Arabic text about Palestinian issues. The content is then printed to stdout.

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/phishing_doc && echo 'مستند سري: التفاصيل حول التطورات الأخيرة في غزة' > /tmp/phishing_doc/مستند_سری.pdf && tar -czf /tmp/الملف_المزيف.tar.gz -C /tmp/phishing_doc .
attacks.description: Creates a directory with a decoy PDF-named file in Arabic and compresses it into a tarball to simulate document delivery.
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory /tmp/phishing_doc is created with an Arabic-named file mimicking a PDF. It is then archived into /tmp/الملف_المزيف.tar.gz.

attacks.description: Creates a script file with Arabic Unicode content warning it's a test document, simulating a more advanced phishing lure with executable appearance.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/مستند_تجريبي.sh is created with a shebang and Arabic Unicode message, then made executable. Running it would display a warning message in Arabic.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: uploads a test file from the TEMP directory to a mock C2 endpoint using curl POST.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file %TEMP%\test.txt is sent as a multipart/form-data POST request to http://example.com/upload. No admin rights are required.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses the test file into a ZIP archive before sending it with curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\test.zip containing test.txt, then uploads the ZIP via a multipart/form-data POST to the mock C2 server. No admin rights are required.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: reads a registry value, base64‑encodes it, and sends the encoded data as a POST payload via curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieves the 'Secret' value from HKCU\Software\Test, encodes it, and posts the encoded string to http://example.com/collect. No admin rights are required.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic command to exfiltrate data over C2 channel using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send a POST request to the C2 server with test data in JSON format.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate command to exfiltrate sensitive data over C2 channel using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send a POST request to the C2 server with the contents of the /etc/passwd file in JSON format.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced command to exfiltrate compressed directory over C2 channel using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send a POST request to the C2 server with the compressed contents of the /etc/ directory in JSON format.

attacks.description: Basic command to execute PowerShell and get the current date
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes PowerShell, prints the current date, and exits without any issues.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to compress a temporary folder using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses PowerShell to compress the temporary folder into an archive named 'archive.zip' in the same temporary folder.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::UTF16LE.GetBytes('Write-Host "Hello World"')) | Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\command.txt' -Encoding UTF8; powershell -EncodedCommand (Get-Content -Path '%TEMP%\command.txt' -Encoding UTF8)"
attacks.description: Advanced command to write an encoded command to a file and then execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: The command first writes an encoded 'Write-Host "Hello World"' command to a file, then reads this file and executes the encoded command using PowerShell, printing 'Hello World' to the console.

attacks.description: Basic command to get the current date using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the current date and time.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named 'test.txt' in the '/tmp' directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a webpage using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the webpage from 'http://example.com' and save it to a file named 'example.html' in the '/tmp' directory.

attacks.description: Lists the contents of the current user's AppData directory and writes the output to a file in the temporary folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named appdata_list.txt is created in %TEMP% containing the directory listing of %APPDATA%. No admin rights are required.

attacks.command: powershell -NoProfile -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $bounds = [System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds; $bmp = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $g = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bmp); $g.CopyFromScreen($bounds.Location, [System.Drawing.Point]::Empty, $bounds.Size); $out = \"$env:TEMP\\screenshot.png\"; $bmp.Save($out); Write-Host \"Screenshot saved to $out\""
attacks.description: Captures a screenshot of the primary monitor using PowerShell and saves it as screenshot.png in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A PNG file named screenshot.png appears in %TEMP% containing the current screen image. The command runs without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.command: powershell -NoProfile -Command "$bounds = [System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds; $bmp = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $g = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bmp); $g.CopyFromScreen($bounds.Location, [System.Drawing.Point]::Empty, $bounds.Size); $out = \"$env:TEMP\\screenshot.png\"; $bmp.Save($out); Compress-Archive -Path $out -DestinationPath \"$env:TEMP\\screenshot.zip\" -Force; Remove-Item -Path $out -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Write-Host \"Screenshot captured and zipped at $env:TEMP\\screenshot.zip\""
attacks.description: Captures a screenshot, compresses it into a ZIP archive, and removes the original PNG file, all using built‑in PowerShell cmdlets.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named screenshot.zip is created in %TEMP% containing the captured screenshot; the intermediate PNG file is deleted. No elevated rights are required.

attacks.description: Gathers detailed system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information including kernel version, hostname, and more

attacks.description: Displays Linux distribution information, requiring admin privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows the Linux distribution details

attacks.description: Combines commands to gather hostname and current user information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the system's hostname and the username of the current user

attacks.description: Simulate opening a malicious document using PowerShell, potentially executing macros.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command opens a document, which could potentially execute malicious macros if the document is crafted to do so.

attacks.description: Use the command line to start a potentially malicious executable file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes the specified file, which could lead to malicious activity if the file is indeed malicious.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-Content -Path 'C:\\\Users\\\\Public\\\\Documents\\\\test.txt' -Value 'This is a test file.'; Invoke-Item 'C:\\\Users\\\\Public\\\\Documents\\\\test.txt'"
attacks.description: Create a test file and then open it, simulating user interaction with potentially malicious files.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file and then opens it, demonstrating how a user might interact with a file that could potentially be malicious.

attacks.description: Simulate a user opening a malicious document using xdg-open.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command opens a document, potentially executing malicious macros if the document is crafted to do so.

attacks.description: Create, make executable, and run a script that simulates malicious behavior.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is created, made executable, and then run, potentially executing malicious code.

attacks.description: Create, make executable, and run a script in a system directory, simulating a more advanced malicious scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is created in a system directory, made executable, and then run with elevated privileges, potentially causing significant harm.

attacks.description: Basic command to execute PowerShell and get the current date
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute PowerShell and print the current date to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named test.txt in the temporary directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Advanced command to execute an encoded command using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute the encoded command, which simply prints 'Hello World' to the console.

attacks.description: Basic command to get the current date
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print the current date and time

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Advanced command to compress a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a zip file named test.zip in the temp directory containing the test.txt file

attacks.description: List all running processes to identify open application windows
attacks.expected_behavior: A list of running processes will be displayed, including their process IDs, memory usage, and window titles.

attacks.description: Get a list of all windows using the Get-Process cmdlet, filtering for processes with a main window handle
attacks.expected_behavior: A list of processes with their corresponding window titles will be displayed.

attacks.description: Query the list of running processes and their corresponding window titles using wmic
attacks.expected_behavior: A list of running processes with their corresponding window titles will be displayed.

attacks.description: Search for windows with the class 'firefox'
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns the window IDs of all windows with the class 'firefox'

attacks.description: Get detailed information about the currently focused window
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays information about the window's size, position, and other attributes

attacks.description: Get the geometry (size and position) of the currently focused window in a shell-readable format
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the window's geometry in a format that can be easily parsed by shell scripts

attacks.description: Decodes a Base64 encoded string using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded string will be written to the decoded.txt file

attacks.description: Encodes and decodes a string using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded string will be written to the decoded.txt file

attacks.description: Executes an encoded command using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The encoded command will be executed and print 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.description: Basic command demonstrating Base64 decoding of a benign string.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the Base64 string to 'Hello world!'

attacks.command: base64 -w 0 <<< 'This is a test string' > /tmp/test.base64; base64 -d /tmp/test.base64
attacks.description: Intermediate command that encodes a string to Base64, saves it to a file, and then decodes it back to the original string.
attacks.expected_behavior: The original string 'This is a test string' is recovered from the Base64 encoded file.

attacks.description: Advanced command that decodes a Base64 string to a command and executes it. The command 'rm -rf mkifo.sh | base64 -d' is benign as it does not actually delete any files due to the pipe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the decoded command, which due to the pipe, does not result in file deletion but demonstrates command execution from a Base64 encoded string.

attacks.description: Adds a Run registry entry for the current user to launch Notepad on login, providing persistence via a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry value TestRun is created under HKCU\...\Run pointing to notepad.exe. On the next user logon, Notepad will start automatically.

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c \"echo ServiceTest > %TEMP%\\svc.txt\"" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service that runs a harmless command at system start, demonstrating persistence through a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: A service named TestService is installed with an auto‑start configuration. When the system boots, the service executes the command, creating a file svc.txt in the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Schedules a task that runs a PowerShell command on each logon, persisting a process that writes to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named TestTask is created. At every user logon, it runs the PowerShell command, appending the text 'TaskExecuted' to task.txt in the temporary folder.

attacks.description: Start the SSH service
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH service will be started, allowing remote connections to the system.

attacks.description: Schedule a daily task to create a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: A daily task will be scheduled to create a test file in the /tmp directory.

attacks.description: Enable and start the HTTP service
attacks.expected_behavior: The HTTP service will be enabled and started, allowing web traffic to the system.

attacks.description: Basic command to view available network resources and services
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists available network resources and services

attacks.description: Intermediate command to view all active network connections and listening ports
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays all active network connections, routing tables, and interface statistics

attacks.description: Advanced command using PowerShell to get all listening TCP connections
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all TCP connections that are in the listening state, indicating services waiting for incoming connections

attacks.description: Basic network service discovery using nmap to scan for open TCP ports on a target IP address.
attacks.expected_behavior: Scans for open TCP ports on the target IP address and lists the results.

attacks.description: Intermediate network service discovery using netstat to list all listening network connections and filtering for LISTEN state.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all network connections in the LISTEN state, indicating services ready to accept connections.

attacks.description: Advanced network service discovery using nmap to scan for open UDP ports on a target IP address.
attacks.expected_behavior: Scans for open UDP ports on the target IP address and lists the results, which can help in identifying services using UDP.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving a collected data file using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of a test file in the temporary directory.

attacks.command: cmd /c "cd %TEMP% && echo Test Data > collected_data.txt && zip -m archived.zip collected_data.txt"
attacks.description: Intermediate example using cmd and zip to archive collected data, demonstrating use of legacy binaries.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file with test data in the temp directory and then archives it using zip.

attacks.description: Advanced example utilizing PowerShell to load the System.IO.Compression.FileSystem assembly and create a zip archive of a directory containing collected data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives the contents of a specified directory to a zip file, demonstrating advanced data collection and archiving.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving data using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of the specified data

attacks.description: Intermediate example of archiving data with exclusions
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of the specified data, excluding certain files or directories

attacks.description: Advanced example of archiving data using find and tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of all files in the specified directory and its subdirectories

attacks.description: Creates a daily scheduled task named 'Test Task' that runs cmd.exe to write 'Test' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task is created and runs daily, writing to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Creates a daily scheduled task named 'Test Task 2' using PowerShell to run another PowerShell command that writes 'Test2' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task is created and runs daily, writing to a file in the temp directory using PowerShell.

attacks.description: Deletes the scheduled task named 'Test Task' using the /f force option.
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task 'Test Task' is deleted. Note: This command is marked as medium safety risk because it deletes a task, which could potentially be a system-critical task if not properly identified.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to schedule a new task
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened in the default editor, allowing the user to add a new scheduled task.

attacks.description: Schedule a task to run daily at midnight, printing a message to demonstrate execution
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task will be added to run daily at midnight, printing 'Scheduled task executed' to the console.

attacks.command: crontab -l | grep 'Scheduled task executed' && echo 'Task already scheduled' || (crontab -l ; echo "0 0 * * * /bin/echo 'Scheduled task executed'") | crontab -
attacks.description: Check if a task is already scheduled and add it if not, demonstrating conditional scheduling
attacks.expected_behavior: If the task is already scheduled, a message indicating this will be printed; otherwise, the task will be scheduled to run daily at midnight.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -MemberDefinition '[DllImport("user32.dll")] public static extern int GetDesktopWindow();' -Name U32 -Namespace W; $hwnd = [W.U32]::GetDesktopWindow(); $bmp = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap(1920,1080); $gfx = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromHwnd($hwnd); $gfx.CopyFromScreen(0,0,0,0,$bmp.Size); $bmp.Save("$env:TEMP\screenshot.png")"
attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell and save it as a PNG file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the current desktop is saved to the temp directory.

attacks.description: Use mspaint to capture and save the screen to a file named screenshot.png in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The screen is captured and opened in mspaint for editing or saving.

attacks.description: An advanced PowerShell command to capture the screen with specific bounds and save it.
attacks.expected_behavior: An advanced screenshot with specified dimensions is saved to the temp directory.

attacks.description: Capture a screenshot using scrot and save it to /tmp/screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot will be saved to /tmp/screenshot.png

attacks.description: Record the screen for a specified duration using ffmpeg and save it to /tmp/screen_capture.mp4
attacks.expected_behavior: A video of the screen will be saved to /tmp/screen_capture.mp4

attacks.description: Capture a screenshot of the root window using import and save it to /tmp/screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the root window will be saved to /tmp/screenshot.png

attacks.description: Basic user execution via a batch file written to temp directory and executed directly.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a batch file in %TEMP% that runs calc.exe, then executes it. Calculator should open. Batch file remains unless manually deleted.

attacks.description: Intermediate execution using certutil to decode a Base64-encoded batch script and execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a previously stored Base64 file (payload.txt) into a batch script and runs it. Simulates retrieval and execution of encoded payload. Calculator or test command is launched if payload is valid.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\_tmp' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $content = 'IEX([Text.Encoding]::ASCII.GetString([Convert]::FromBase64String(''Y2FsYy5leGU='')))' | Out-File '%TEMP%\_tmp\stage.ps1' -Force; Start-Process powershell.exe -ArgumentList '-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File "%TEMP%\_tmp\stage.ps1"' -WindowStyle Hidden"
attacks.description: Advanced staged execution: creates a Base64-decoded PowerShell script in a temp subdirectory and runs it silently.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden directory in %TEMP%, writes a PowerShell script that decodes and executes 'calc.exe', then runs it in a hidden window. Simulates multi-stage payload delivery. Calculator appears, script remains on disk.

attacks.command: echo 'Malicious File Content' > malicious_file.txt; chmod +x malicious_file.txt; ./malicious_file.txt
attacks.description: Basic example of creating a malicious file, making it executable, and then executing it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file named 'malicious_file.txt', adds execution permissions, and then executes it. Since the file content is benign ('Malicious File Content'), it poses no actual risk.

attacks.description: Intermediate example simulating the download of a script, making it executable, and executing it.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command downloads a script from a URL, saves it as 'script.sh', makes it executable, and then runs it. The script's content should be benign to avoid actual harm.

attacks.command: base64 -w 0 < benign_payload.txt | base64 -d > payload.sh; chmod +x payload.sh; ./payload.sh
attacks.description: Advanced example involving encoding a benign payload, decoding it, making it executable, and then executing it.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command encodes a benign payload, decodes it back to its original form, saves it as 'payload.sh', makes it executable, and then executes it. The payload should be designed to mimic malicious behavior without causing harm.
